title: How to Germinate a Plum Seed & Grow a Plum Tree

steps.title: Harvest the seeds in the summer when plums are at their ripest.
steps.content: Harvest the seeds in the summer when plums are at their ripest. Late summer (around August) is the best month to enjoy plums and remove their seeds. [1] X Trustworthy Source Royal Horticultural Society Leading gardening charity in the U.K. providing resources for identifying, growing and caring for flowers and other plants Go to source Look for plums that are deep purple and slightly soft to the touch. If the plum is still rock-hard, it isn’t ripe yet. [2] X Trustworthy Source Royal Horticultural Society Leading gardening charity in the U.K. providing resources for identifying, growing and caring for flowers and other plants Go to source If you want to ripen a plum faster, leave it on the counter next to a banana. The banana produces ethylene, which will speed up the plum’s ripening process.

steps.title: Remove the pits from the centers of the plums.
steps.content: Remove the pits from the centers of the plums. The easiest way to do this is to simply eat the plum ! Feel free to cut away the meat of the plum with a knife if you prefer; just make sure that you remove the majority of the plum’s flesh from its center pit. [3] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source Use the plums to make delicious recipes, like plum cake, if you don’t want to eat them raw.

steps.title: Dry the pits on a sunny windowsill for 3-4 days.
steps.content: Dry the pits on a sunny windowsill for 3-4 days. A dry pit is much easier to crack than a moist one. Put the pits on a paper towel and set them off to the side somewhere they won’t be disturbed. [4] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source The sunnier the windowsill, the faster the pits will dry out. You can try to germinate the plum pits without removing the seeds first, but most people have better success when they dry out the pits and harvest the seeds.

steps.title: Crack the pits with a small hammer or nutcracker to remove the seeds.
steps.content: Crack the pits with a small hammer or nutcracker to remove the seeds. Once the pits are dry to the touch, gently tap them with a small hammer or squeeze them with a nutcracker to break them open. Inside each pit is a small seed shaped like an almond. Remove them from the pits and set them to the side. [5] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source Go ahead and discard the pits or add them to a compost pile . Note : Plum seeds do not require scarification. There is no hard coat over the seed that you need to scratch or file in order for the seed to germinate. The seeds only need to be removed from the pits. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Test the viability of the seeds by dropping them into a glass of water.
steps.content: Test the viability of the seeds by dropping them into a glass of water. Use cold tap water to fill the glass. If the seeds sink, they are viable and have a chance of germinating. If they float, they are not viable, so discard them. [7] X Research source Seeds that sink contain important nutrients that help them germinate . Seeds that float don’t have these important nutrients or are damaged, preventing them from germinating.

steps.title: Wrap the seeds in a wet paper towel.
steps.content: Wrap the seeds in a wet paper towel. After testing the seeds for viability, remove them from the glass of water. Wet a sheet of paper towel and wring it out so it's damp but not soaking wet. Lay it out flat on a counter and fold it in half. Then, place the seeds on the bottom half and fold the top half over so they’re completely covered. [8] X Research source Using a paper towel to germinate the seeds often produces results much faster than other methods. Instead of waiting a full 12 weeks for roots to sprout, you may start seeing growth after 2 weeks. As an alternative to paper towels, plant specialist Rachel Guffey also recommends “wrapping the seeds in damp sphagnum moss and putting them into an empty strawberry container” or plastic bag “for germination.” Damp sand works, too. [9] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source

steps.title: Place the wet paper towel in a resealable plastic bag.
steps.content: Place the wet paper towel in a resealable plastic bag. Carefully pick up the paper towel and set it inside a plastic bag. Expel as much excess air from the bag as you can before you close it. [10] X Research source Keep the bag flat if you can. This will make it less likely that a seed will slip out from the paper towel.

steps.title: Store the plastic bag in the refrigerator at 40 °F (4 °C).
steps.content: Store the plastic bag in the refrigerator at 40 °F (4 °C). Check the temperature of your fridge and lower it if it is higher than 40 °F (4 °C). Put the plastic bag somewhere it won’t get squished. [11] X Research source Keeping the seeds in the fridge mimics the process that would take place if the plum were to have fallen to the ground after the summer growing season ended. The plum would break open, and the pit would spend several months in the cold winter earth. This process is called stratification and is necessary for the seeds to sprout roots. So, Guffey says the seeds need cold stratification to germinate indoors.

steps.title: Wait 2-12 weeks for the seeds to grow roots.
steps.content: Wait 2-12 weeks for the seeds to grow roots. Depending on the seeds, it can take anywhere from several weeks to several months for roots to appear. Check the seeds every 2 weeks by opening the plastic bag and peeking into the paper towel. The roots will be small and white when they first appear, and they will turn green as they get bigger. [13] X Research source Even after the seeds start to root, you can leave them in the fridge. They won’t be ready to be planted in soil or go outside until the springtime. Not every seed will grow roots. If after 12 weeks a seed still doesn’t show any signs of growth, you can throw it out.

steps.title: Dampen the paper towel when it gets dry.
steps.content: Dampen the paper towel when it gets dry. When you check the seeds for progress, check the paper towel, too. If it is dry to the touch, carefully remove it from the plastic bag and sprinkle it with water so it gets damp again. Reseal it in the bag and place it back in the fridge. [14] X Research source Keep doing this until the springtime when you can transfer the seeds to pots.

steps.title: Fill a small container with 5-6 inches (13-15 cm) of well-draining soil.
steps.content: Fill a small container with 5-6 inches (13-15 cm) of well-draining soil . You can use a small pot or even plastic cups for your seeds. They don’t need a lot of space at first, so opt for a container with a 4 to 6 in (10 to 15 cm) circumference. This gives each seed enough space to grow for at least 6 months. [15] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source Look for well-draining soil at your local home and garden store.

steps.title: Plant the seeds 2 in (5 cm) deep in the soil and water them thoroughly.
steps.content: Plant the seeds 2 in (5 cm) deep in the soil and water them thoroughly. Make a small hole in the center of each container with your finger. Drop a seed into the hole , and then cover it up with soil. Then, water the soil until it is damp to the touch. [16] X Research source If you’re concerned about excess water coming out of the bottom of the containers, set them on a drainage plate.

steps.title: Put the containers somewhere they’ll receive 6 hours of sun every day.
steps.content: Put the containers somewhere they’ll receive 6 hours of sun every day. Keep the seedlings indoors until the last threat of frost passes. Then, gradually harden them off to the outdoors before keeping them outside. If you live in a cooler climate, keep the containers in a sheltered area, like a garage or shed, and use a plant light to ensure they get enough sun each day. [17] X Trustworthy Source Royal Horticultural Society Leading gardening charity in the U.K. providing resources for identifying, growing and caring for flowers and other plants Go to source More than 6 hours of sun a day is perfectly fine. They just need that at a minimum to thrive. To harden off the seedlings, expose them to a few hours of partial shade outdoors. Then, gradually increase the time they’re outside and the amount of sun they get each day. Make sure the seedlings stay warm, between 65 to 75° F (18-24° C). If your area isn’t that warm yet, place a heat mat under the pot.

steps.title: Water the soil when the top 2 inches (5.1 cm) are dry to the touch.
steps.content: Water the soil when the top 2 inches (5.1 cm) are dry to the touch. If the containers are outside, rainwater should be enough for the seeds unless there is a dry spell of more than 5 days. If the plants are indoors, check them every 2-3 days to see if they need more water or not. [18] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source Over the weeks, you should see new green growth break through the soil. Plum trees are pretty hardy, so other than giving them water and sun, there isn’t too much else you have to do other than be patient.

steps.title: Transplant the seeds into the ground or into bigger pots.
steps.content: Transplant the seeds into the ground or into bigger pots. Once the tree has begun to grow several inches tall and the threat of frost is past, feel free to transplant it into your garden in the spring. Simply dig a hole as deep as the container and twice as wide. [19] X Trustworthy Source Penn State Extension Educational organization dedicated to delivering science-based information to people, businesses, and communities Go to source Or, keep it in its container and repot it every 6 to 12 months, or whenever the spread of its leaves and roots outstretch the perimeter of its current container. [20] X Trustworthy Source Royal Horticultural Society Leading gardening charity in the U.K. providing resources for identifying, growing and caring for flowers and other plants Go to source Make sure you choose a spot in your garden that gets bright, direct light for at least 6 hours and where the soil is well draining (doesn’t accumulate standing water). Most plum trees start producing fruit after 3-5 years.

steps.title: Mulch around the base of the tree to retain moisture and repel weeds.
steps.content: Mulch around the base of the tree to retain moisture and repel weeds. Add a layer of mulch in a circle around the base of the plum tree that’s 2 to 3 inches (5-7.6 cm) thick and 1 foot (30 cm) wide. Just leave about 2 inches (5 cm) of space between the tree trunk and the mulch . This helps your tree retain moisture and prevents weeds from growing. [21] X Research source Placing mulch directly against the tree can encourage fungus and bacteria to grow, which can harm your tree. [22] X Research source

steps.title: Fertilize the trees once a year to encourage their growth.
steps.content: Fertilize the trees once a year to encourage their growth. During the next spring, apply a plum tree fertilizer or low-nitrogen fertilizer with a 1-1-1 ratio of nitrogen to phosphorus to potassium. Apply the fertilizer after the last frost so the trees can absorb the nutrients before they enter the growing season. [23] X Trustworthy Source University of Georgia Cooperative Extension Division of the University of Georgia focused on research and community education Go to source Always wear gloves when working with fertilizer and follow the directions to mix and disperse it properly. Some fertilizers need to be diluted with water and sprayed around the roots of the trees, while others get sprinkled over the ground dry. Note: Do not fertilize your prune tree during its first year. Applying fertilizer can prevent its roots from growing properly, which can affect your tree’s health down the line. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Prune the trees in the summer to help them produce more fruit.
steps.content: Prune the trees in the summer to help them produce more fruit. Use sharp, clean pruning shears to remove any dead, diseased, or dying branches. Then, trim off any branches that are crossing or touching. Cut them off at a 45-degree angle where they intersect with the trunk. [25] X Research source In general, avoid cutting away any branches until they’re at least 3 years old unless they are obviously diseased or dead.

steps.title: Protect the trees from freezing temperatures.
steps.content: Protect the trees from freezing temperatures. Exposure to freezing temperatures in the fall, winter, and spring can damage your plum tree’s trunk and branches and prevent it from producing fruit. Before the first frost in your area, paint the trunk with a 50/50 mixture of white latex paint and water. [26] X Research source Or, wrap the trunk with a trunk protector (paper or plastic). [27] X Research source Painting the trunk white helps reflect sunlight, which prevents the bark from fluctuating in temperature and cracking. Repaint the trunk about every 2 years.
